newsitem.title: ISRAEL: U.S. envoy meets Israeli, Palestinian leaders.
newsitem.headline: U.S. envoy meets Israeli, Palestinian leaders.

text.p: U.S. President Bill Clinton's special envoy launched a Middle East peace mission on Sunday, trying to restore Israeli-PLO security cooperation following a bloody suicide attack.

"The president and the secretary want me to focus on the security questions and I will be doing that," envoy Dennis Ross told reporters after meeting Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for 2-1/2 hours.

Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright dispatched Ross to ease tensions heightened by a July 30 suicide attack which killed 15 people including the two Islamic militant bombers at a Jerusalem market.

Underscoring the difficulties facing Ross, Palestinian officials insisted as he headed into a meeting with Palestinian President Yasser Arafat that the envoy's mission must not be limited to security concerns.
"We cannot confine the talks to security issues," Information Minister Yasser Abed Rabbo told Reuters before the meeting in the self-ruled West Bank town of Ramallah.
"This is the Palestinian leadership's decision -- that all issues should be discussed with Ross in order to reach positive results," Abed Rabbo said.

Ross said earlier that Clinton and Albright recognised there was "a political dimension that has to be addressed but they also understand that there is an essential security underpinning to the (peace) process".

Arafat wants Israel to ease a security clampdown on Palestinians. Netanyahu closed off the West Bank and Gaza after the market attack and conditioned any resumption of talks on Arafat cracking down on Islamic militant groups.
In a television interview with Reuters and CNN on Saturday, Arafat said he was making a "100 percent effort" to arrest militants trying to wreck peace moves.
Ignoring a public U.S. appeal to both sides to tone down their war of words, Arafat on Saturday accused Israel of waging "state terrorism" against his people as punishment for the market attack.

"What we see are tricks, misleading actions and evasions and an attempt to divert world attention and even the Israeli public," countered Netanyahu's foreign policy adviser Uzi Arad in an army radio interview on Sunday.
Arafat also said on Saturday that he would raise with Ross the issue of Israel's Jewish settlement policy on land occupied since the 1967 Middle East war.
Netanyahu's decision to start work on the Jewish settlement of Har Homa in Arab East Jerusalem in March led to a freeze in substantive peace negotiations with Arafat's PLO.
Palestinians view the construction on a hill they call Jabal Abu Ghneim as a unilateral violation of their peace deals.
"There is no connection between the construction in Har Homa and the settlements...and the terrorism," Netanyahu's communications chief David Bar-Illan said.
"There's no chance that we will stop the construction on Har Homa or that the Americans would demand that," Bar-Illan told Israel's Channel One television.

The Israeli army lifted an "inner closure" in parts of the West Bank on Sunday, allowing Palestinians to travel between three besieged self-ruled cities, Jenin, Tulkarm and Qalqilya. It gave no reason for the move.
It opened crossings linking the West Bank and Gaza with Jordan and Egypt for travel by Palestinians and others.

Israeli soldiers would continue to surround the West Bank cities of Hebron, Ramallah and Bethlehem and an overall ban on Palestinians entering Israel remained in effect, the army said. A siege of Jericho and Nablus was lifted on Friday.

Ross, on his first mission since May, said he would also be preparing for a possible first visit to the region by Albright. She had said she was prepared to visit at the end of the month provided progress was made on security.
Her trip would likely be aimed at finding ways to wrap up outstanding issues from interim Israel-PLO deals and pursue accelerated talks on a final peace settlement.

On Friday Arafat said Israel had informed him the bombers came from abroad. Arafat also suggested in television interviews on Saturday that the pro-Iranian Hizbollah group in Lebanon may have been linked to the attack.
Israeli security officials say they do not know the bombers' origins and say the attackers in any event get orders and support from areas under Arafat's control.
